awd_titl_txt: QII-TAQS: Spatially and Temporally Resolved Ultrasensitive Magnetic Sensing of Quantum Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project aims to develop a quantum mechanical magnetic camera (QMMC) for spatial and temporal imaging of ultra-weak magnetic fields that arise on the surfaces of quantum materials. Such a camera will obtain detailed information about intricate spatial correlations, providing novel information about the nature of quantum states. The research aims to improve the magnetic sensitivity of magnetic tunneling junction sensors and integrated sensor arrays. The team of researchers in quantum materials science, magnetic sensing, and semiconductor integrated circuits has the capability of synthesizing quantum materials, fabricating devices, characterizing them with advanced resonance techniques, and developing theoretical understanding of quantum mechanisms and phenomena. The camera is intended to become a magnetic "visual" tool, not only for exotic quantum materials, but also for any two-dimensional active object emitting a spatial and/or temporal magnetic field profile. The expected outcome is expected to be transformative in terms of a broadened scope of high-end applications currently not available due to small field signals. The findings will advance the fields of both strongly correlated-electron matter and quantum information science. The research activities will also enable student entrepreneurs to create start-up companies that convert the QMMC prototypes into high performance QMMC products. In addition, the research team is collaboratively developing a new quantum information science course and organizing a summer workshop for graduate students and researchers in New England and beyond.  

This project brings together a multidisciplinary team of researchers with expertise in quantum sensing, nanoscale fabrication, synthesis and characterization of quantum materials, as well as theoretical modeling, to develop a quantum mechanical magnetic camera (QMMC), providing spatial and temporal imaging of ultra-weak magnetic fields with unprecedented sensitivity and - in fully optimized implementation - submicron spatial resolution over macroscopically large areas. The sensor is based on magnetic tunneling junction (MTJ) technology. With QMMC, the research team obtains detailed information about the intricate spatial correlations and local polarization of the topological quantum states. These unique measurements provide valuable tests of theoretical predictions of quantum correlations in interacting electron matter and verify the potential of these materials for construction of high-performance qubits with sufficiently long coherence times. The key to the success of the project is to significantly improve the magnetic sensitivity of the MTJ sensors and integrate sensor arrays with dedicated readout circuitry. The research team will explore new quantum tunneling barrier materials that reduce the intrinsic noise of the MTJ and design new multilayer structure to enhance coherent magnetic tunneling. The MTJ sensors will be integrated with CMOS read-out circuits so that both spatial and temporal magnetic fields can be measured and processed. The QMMC not only allows emergent quantum phenomena to be studied in quantum materials, but also expands the applications of quantum magnetic sensors to modern metrology. The team is also developing a unique probe for the study of spatial and temporal correlations on the scales relevant for quantum phenomena. QMMC technology is a significant leap from state-of-the-art technology, representing a paradigm shift in the manufacturing engineering of arrayed quantum sensing devices. The research will expand engineering knowledge in quantum magnetic sensing devices and integration of modern MTJ metal-based cells with more conventional CMOS technology. The research team will nurture student entrepreneurs to develop and manufacture high performance QMMC products.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This QII-TAQS project at Brown University represents a hallmark of commitment and innovation in the exploration of quantum magnetic sensing. Over the years, this initiative has been a testament to the persistent endeavors of a devoted team, whose aspirations have been rooted in the profound mysteries of quantum and spintronic materials. The project's journey has been characterized by an unwavering dedication to enhancing our capabilities, enabling us to observe and understand these complex materials with a high level of detail and sensitivity.

At the heart of the project has been the intellectual pursuit to develop an advanced magnetic sensor array, leveraging quantum magnetic tunnel junctions (MTJs). This ambitious goal was not merely a technological advancement but a deeper dive into the behaviors that quantum materials exhibit. The project has not only pushed the boundaries of existing technology but has also expanded our comprehension of quantum materials. The team's efforts have led to enhancements in MTJ sensor sensitivity, development of CMOS circuits for the sensor arrays and their integration, shedding light on novel topological materials and their functionalities, exploring new quantum magnets, and ushering in the era of ultra-sensitive magnetic imaging devices. Furthermore, we have made strides in refining spin noise detection techniques, which have advanced our understanding of quantum entanglement in materials. Theoretical support provided by the project has been instrumental, offering fresh perspectives on magnetic field interactions within quantum materials and fostering a synergy between groundbreaking theoretical and experimental approaches. This, in turn, has enriched the scientific community's collective knowledge base.

The broader impacts of the QII-TAQS project extend far beyond the confines of laboratory walls. In the realm of educational advancement, the project has played a pivotal role in nurturing a new generation of scientists and engineers. By integrating quantum science into the curriculum at Brown University and making concerted efforts to engage with underrepresented groups in STEM, the project has contributed significantly to shaping the future of scientific education and to the development of skilled human resources. Moreover, the project has taken strides in public engagement, with efforts aimed at demystifying the complex world of quantum physics for the broader community through public talks and educational outreach. These initiatives have not only sparked curiosity but have also inspired the next generation of scientists.

Innovation and commercialization have been key facets of the QII-TAQS project, with the research leading to the filing of patents for cutting-edge magnetic sensing technologies. These advancements, particularly in computing functions using skyrmions, hold the potential to revolutionize various industries, ranging from healthcare to cybersecurity. Furthermore, the societal benefits of the project have been profound, contributing to public policy discussions and helping to forge a society that deeply values and supports scientific inquiry for the collective betterment of humanity.

As we reflect on the QII-TAQS project at Brown University, it is clear that it stands as a guiding light of innovation and discovery in the field of quantum materials research. The contributions of the project, spanning advanced sensor development, theoretical insights, and educational advancements, have laid a solid foundation for future explorations. The potential applications of our work, from medical diagnostics and environmental monitoring to quantum computing, hold the promise of fundamentally transforming our world. This reflects the enduring impact of our endeavor on science, technology, and society at large, underscoring the modest yet profound contributions of the QII-TAQS project to the advancement of knowledge and the betterment of our global community.
